abstract.text: Perform transcendental and trigonometric functions on vectors of any length.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The vForce library provides a range of trigonometric and transcendental functions that work over large collections of single- and double-precision values. The collections can be of any length, and vForce supplies vectorized functions for the current architecture.
The functions declared in the vForce library have the customary mathematical names, but with the prefix
. Each mathematical function is available in two variants: one for single-precision data and one for double-precision data. The single-precision forms have the suffix
, whereas the double-precision forms have no suffix. For example,
is the single-precision cosine function, and
All of the vForce library functions follow a common format:
The first parameter points to an array to hold the results. The only exceptions are
, which have two result arrays that the first two parameters point to.
One or more parameters point to operand arrays that are the same length as the result array.
The last parameter is the array length.
Unless otherwise mentioned, vForce functions work in-place. That is, the input may exactly equal the output.
The vForce library provides a high-performance alternative to
when applying operations on arrays of floating-point values.
For example, given an arbitrarily sized array,
, that contains single-precision values, the following code uses
contains the square root of each array element.
The equivalent functionality implemented in vForce runs significantly faster:

code: let y = [Float](unsafeUninitializedCapacity: n) { buffer, initializedCount in
